Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Situation2: The weekly group meditation meets for an hour today.
Story:
I glance at my phone, reading his message: “Let’s have dinner tonight? Just us.” My heart warms. We haven’t had a quiet evening together in weeks, and I know how much it means to him when I’m fully present, laughing and sharing stories over our favorite noodles. I want to say yes, to give him my time, to be the girlfriend who makes him feel cherished.

But tonight is also the weekly group meditation at the temple. It’s the one hour I dedicate to sitting in silence, breathing with others, letting go of the week’s noise. My teacher always says consistency is the heart of practice, and I promised myself I’d show up, not just for me, but for the sangha. I feel the tug—his hope for closeness, my own commitment to mindfulness. My mind races, torn between the warmth of his hand and the quiet of the meditation hall. I want to be both: the loving partner and the devoted practitioner. The weight of choosing presses on my chest, and I sit, phone in hand, unable to type a reply.
